evidence: Cosimo gave Ficino a villa at Careggi and commissioned translations of Hermetic and Platonic texts. Documented in Ficino's letters and biographical accounts.
Cosimo established the Academy by providing Ficino with the villa at Careggi and commissioning translations that became its intellectual foundation.
Ficino was the intellectual center of the Academy, hosting discussions and producing the translations that defined its mission.
After Cosimo's death, Piero continued the family's support of Ficino during his brief rule.
Lorenzo continued Medici patronage of Ficino and was himself a participant in Academy discussions. Documented in Ficino's letters.
Lorenzo brought Poliziano into his household as tutor to his children and supported his scholarly work.
Lorenzo protected Pico after his condemnation by the Pope and welcomed him into the Academy circle.
Lorenzo supported Landino's scholarly work, including his influential commentary on Dante.
Ficino was the intellectual leader of the Academy until his death, hosting discussions and directing its translation program.
Pico became a key member of Ficino's circle after arriving in Florence, contributing his unique synthesis of traditions.
Poliziano participated in Academy discussions while serving the Medici household.
Landino was an early member of Ficino's circle, applying Neoplatonic ideas to his literary criticism.
Benivieni participated in Academy discussions and wrote poetry influenced by Ficinian love philosophy.
Diacceto was Ficino's most devoted pupil and continued the Academy's work after the master's death.
Cavalcanti participated in Academy discussions; Ficino dedicated dialogues to him.
The Academy met at the villa Cosimo provided to Ficino at Careggi.
Pletho's lectures on Plato at the Council of Florence (1439) inspired Cosimo to establish the Platonic Academy. Documented by later Academy members.
Ficino studied Greek under Argyropoulos in Florence, gaining the skills needed for his translation work.
Poliziano studied under Argyropoulos, developing his mastery of Greek philology.
Lorenzo studied philosophy under Argyropoulos as part of his humanist education.
Pico corresponded extensively with Ficino and was influenced by his Neoplatonic synthesis, though bringing his own Kabbalistic interests.
Diacceto was Ficino's most devoted student and became his philosophical successor.
Corsi studied with Ficino and later wrote his biography, preserving firsthand knowledge of the Academy.
Poliziano served as tutor to Lorenzo's children, including the future Pope Leo X.
Lorenzo participated in Academy discussions and his poetry shows Neoplatonic influence from Ficino.
Bessarion's defense of Platonism against Aristotelian critics shaped the intellectual climate in which Ficino worked.
Ficino and Bessarion exchanged letters and shared Greek manuscripts; documented in Ficino's correspondence.
Chrysoloras's earlier introduction of Greek teaching to Florence (1397) established the tradition Argyropoulos continued.
Both scholars worked on Greek texts in Florence during the same period, collaborating on editions and scholarship.
Ficino translated the Corpus Hermeticum at Cosimo's urgent request, completing it before Plato. Published as De potestate et sapientia Dei.
Ficino's complete Latin translation of Plato, finished in 1484, made Plato fully accessible to the Latin West for the first time.
Ficino's major philosophical work, arguing for the soul's immortality through Neoplatonic philosophy.
Ficino's controversial work on health, astrology, and natural magic.
Ficino's commentary on Plato's Symposium, developing the concept of 'Platonic love' that became hugely influential.
Ficino's translation of Plotinus, published in 1492, made systematic Neoplatonism available in Latin.
Cosimo prioritized this first treatise of the Hermetica, wanting to read it before he died. Ficino completed it swiftly.
Ficino translated and used the Orphic Hymns in Academy rituals, seeing them as part of the ancient wisdom tradition.
Pico's famous oration intended as the opening speech for his proposed debate on the 900 theses.
Pico's compilation of 900 propositions from all major philosophical and religious traditions, condemned by the Pope.
Pico's sevenfold mystical commentary on Genesis, demonstrating his synthesis of Kabbalah and Neoplatonism.
Landino's influential commentary interpreting Dante through a Neoplatonic lens.
The Enneads are Plotinus's collected philosophical writings, organized by his student Porphyry.
The Hermetic texts were attributed to Hermes Trismegistus; Renaissance scholars believed this literally, modern scholars date them to 2nd-3rd c. CE.
The Asclepius was attributed to Hermes Trismegistus and known throughout the medieval period in Latin.
The Pimander (Poimandres) is the first treatise attributed to Hermes Trismegistus.
The Orphic Hymns were attributed to the legendary Orpheus; Renaissance scholars believed in his ancient authorship.
Plotinus developed his philosophy as a systematic interpretation of Plato's dialogues.
Proclus developed Plotinian Neoplatonism into a more elaborate systematic structure.
Iamblichus studied under Porphyry (Plotinus's student) and developed Neoplatonism in a more religious direction.
Pseudo-Dionysius heavily borrowed from Proclus's Neoplatonic philosophy, Christianizing it.
Ficino devoted his life to translating and interpreting Plato, seeing him as a divinely inspired philosopher.
Ficino translated and commented on Plotinus, adopting his systematic metaphysics of emanation.
Ficino believed Hermes was an ancient Egyptian sage who had received divine revelation; the Hermetic texts shaped his magical and religious thought.
Ficino translated and studied Proclus's works on Platonic theology.
Iamblichus's emphasis on theurgy and ritual influenced Ficino's ideas about natural magic in De vita.
Ficino saw Pseudo-Dionysius as evidence that Platonic philosophy was compatible with Christianity.
Ficino placed Orpheus in the prisca theologia and used Orphic hymns in Academy rituals.
Ficino included Pythagoras in the chain of ancient wisdom and valued Pythagorean number mysticism.
Ficino placed Zoroaster at the beginning of the prisca theologia as the first sage to receive divine wisdom.
Pico's philosophy drew heavily on Platonic ideas, particularly regarding the soul's divine origin.
Pico incorporated Hermetic ideas into his 900 theses and philosophical synthesis.
Pico valued Pythagorean number mysticism, which he connected to Kabbalistic letter-number correspondences.
Pletho was a devoted Platonist who sought to revive ancient Greek religion based on Platonic philosophy.
Landino interpreted Dante's poetry through Neoplatonic philosophy, seeing the Divine Comedy as an allegory of the soul's ascent.
Pico and Ficino exchanged extensive correspondence and mutually influenced each other's philosophical development.
Pico and Poliziano were close friends who died within weeks of each other in 1494.
Both served the Medici and participated in Academy discussions; Poliziano aided with Greek texts.
Benivieni was a close friend of Pico; Pico wrote a commentary on Benivieni's love poetry.
Reuchlin visited Italy and was influenced by Ficino's Neoplatonism, later applying it to Hebrew studies.
Reuchlin met Pico in Italy and was inspired to develop Christian Kabbalah, carrying it to Germany.
Agrippa's Three Books of Occult Philosophy heavily draws on Ficino's natural magic and astrology.
Agrippa incorporated Pico's Christian Kabbalah and magical philosophy into his occult synthesis.
Bruno developed Ficino's Hermeticism into a radical cosmological philosophy.
Bruno was deeply influenced by Hermetic philosophy, seeing it as ancient Egyptian wisdom.
Patrizi continued the Florentine Neoplatonic tradition, defending Plato against Aristotle.
Diacceto was recognized as Ficino's philosophical successor and continued teaching Neoplatonism in Florence.
Savonarola's puritanical regime disrupted the Academy's activities; his followers burned 'vanities' including classical texts.
Savonarola preached against Medici luxury and rule, though Lorenzo initially tolerated him.
Cosimo gave Ficino the villa at Careggi where he lived and worked for most of his life.
Ficino spent his entire career in Florence and its environs.
Pletho attended the Council of Florence as part of the Byzantine delegation seeking union with Rome.
Bessarion attended the Council as a prominent Byzantine churchman and remained in Italy after its conclusion.
Cosimo was the de facto ruler of Florence and head of the Medici bank.
Lorenzo ruled Florence as its leading citizen during its golden age.
Pico died in Florence on November 17, 1494, possibly poisoned.
Poliziano died in Florence on September 24, 1494, weeks before Pico.
Cosimo was the effective ruler of Florence from 1434 until his death.
Lorenzo was the de facto ruler of Florence during its cultural golden age.
Ficino's Platonic Theology draws extensively on Plotinian metaphysics and the structure of emanation.
Ficino incorporates Hermetic ideas about the dignity and divinity of the human soul.
De Amore is explicitly a commentary on Plato's Symposium.
De Vita draws on Hermetic ideas about celestial influences and natural magic.
Pico's Oration quotes Hermes Trismegistus on the nature of man as a great miracle.
Several of Pico's 900 theses draw on Hermetic philosophy.
Heptaplus develops ideas from Pico's Kabbalistic theses into a full mystical commentary on Genesis.
Landino interprets Dante through Neoplatonic philosophy, seeing the journey as the soul's ascent.
Plotinus's Enneads are a systematic interpretation and development of Platonic philosophy.
The Pimander is the first and most important treatise within the Corpus Hermeticum.
The Asclepius is part of the broader Hermetic literature, though surviving separately in Latin.
Ficino's encounter with the Hermetica profoundly shaped his philosophical vision of ancient wisdom.
Plotinus's systematic metaphysics provided the framework for Ficino's own philosophical system.
The 900 theses represent Pico's ambitious attempt to synthesize all philosophical traditions.
